40.title: Recipes: Dynamic routes
40.headline: Recipes: Dynamic routes
40.body:
When creating frontend routing, often you might want to map a route by a given pattern. To achieve this,
dynamic routing is needed. 
Example of a case where dynamic routing could be used is when creating a user view with a dynamic ID to differentiate between multiple users. 
const  routes =  [ 
    {  path:  "" ,  component:  "front-page"  } , 
    {  path:  "user" ,  component:  "user-list"  } , 
    {  path:  "user/:id" ,  component:  "user-profile"  } , 
] ; 
  
When navigating to /user/123 , the id  property of the view will be provided the paramter from the URL, in this case 123 .

56.title: Recipes: Error pages
56.headline: Recipes: Error pages
56.body:
Simplr router supports 2 kinds of error pages by default: 

Not found -page 
Forbidden/Unauthorized -page 
 
These have special routings set up for them inside the router, and are programmed into the router. 
In action this means that if a not found -page is set in the routes, it will be displayed by the router in a case
where the route provided by the user is not found on the application.

80.title: Getting started: Using a starter
80.headline: Initial setup
80.body:
Start by initializing your project with the Open-WC starter 
npm  init @open-wc
  
This will prompt you to generate a starter application for your web component project. You should choose to create
an application, and add whatever optional tooling you need. 
The setup we're using in this tutorial is as follows: 
✔ What would you like to do today? › Scaffold a new project
✔ What would you like to scaffold? › Application
✔ What would you like to add? ›
✔ Would you like to use typescript? › No
✔ What is the tag name of your application/web component? … simplr-router-demo

81.title: Getting started: Using a starter
81.headline: Installing the router
81.body:
npm  install  @simplr-wc/router
  
This command will install the Simplr Router to your project and will be ready to use as soon as it's finished installing.

1u.title: Recipes: Dynamic routes
1u.headline: Recipes: Dynamic routes
1u.body:
When creating frontend routing, often you might want to map a route by a given pattern. To achieve this,
dynamic routing is needed. 
Example of a case where dynamic routing could be used is when creating a user view with a dynamic ID to differentiate between multiple users. 
const  routes =  [ 
    {  path:  "" ,  component:  "front-page"  } , 
    {  path:  "user" ,  component:  "user-list"  } , 
    {  path:  "user/:id" ,  component:  "user-profile"  } , 
] ; 
  
When navigating to /user/123 , the id  property of the view will be provided the paramter from the URL, in this case 123 .

1y.title: Recipes: Guards
1y.headline: Recipes: Guards
1y.body:
Route guards can be used to prevent access to certain pages from users. 
Guards are a programmatic interface that allows you to create custom guard functions to check if the current user is authorized to
view a route.

8b.title: Recipes: Dynamic routes
8b.headline: Recipes: Dynamic routes
8b.body:
When creating frontend routing, often you might want to map a route by a given pattern. To achieve this,
dynamic routing is needed. 
Example of a case where dynamic routing could be used is when creating a user view with a dynamic ID to differentiate between multiple users. 
const  routes =  [ 
    {  path:  "" ,  component:  "front-page"  } , 
    {  path:  "user" ,  component:  "user-list"  } , 
    {  path:  "user/:id" ,  component:  "user-profile"  } , 
] ; 
  
When navigating to /user/123 , the id  property of the view will be provided the paramter from the URL, in this case 123 .

a6.title: Getting started: Using a starter
a6.headline: Initial setup
a6.body:
Start by initializing your project with the Open-WC starter 
npm  init @open-wc
  
This will prompt you to generate a starter application for your web component project. You should choose to create
an application, and add whatever optional tooling you need. 
The setup we're using in this tutorial is as follows: 
✔ What would you like to do today? › Scaffold a new project
✔ What would you like to scaffold? › Application
✔ What would you like to add? ›
✔ Would you like to use typescript? › No
✔ What is the tag name of your application/web component? … simplr-router-demo

a7.title: Getting started: Using a starter
a7.headline: Installing the router
a7.body:
npm  install  @simplr-wc/router
  
This command will install the Simplr Router to your project and will be ready to use as soon as it's finished installing.

dr.title: Recipes: Dynamic routes
dr.headline: Recipes: Dynamic routes
dr.body:
When creating frontend routing, often you might want to map a route by a given pattern. To achieve this,
dynamic routing is needed. 
Example of a case where dynamic routing could be used is when creating a user view with a dynamic ID to differentiate between multiple users. 
const  routes =  [ 
    {  path:  "" ,  component:  "front-page"  } , 
    {  path:  "user" ,  component:  "user-list"  } , 
    {  path:  "user/:id" ,  component:  "user-profile"  } , 
] ; 
  
When navigating to /user/123 , the id  property of the view will be provided the paramter from the URL, in this case 123 .

i3.title: Recipes: Dynamic routes
i3.headline: Recipes: Dynamic routes
i3.body:
When creating frontend routing, often you might want to map a route by a given pattern. To achieve this,
dynamic routing is needed. 
Example of a case where dynamic routing could be used is when creating a user view with a dynamic ID to differentiate between multiple users. 
const  routes =  [ 
    {  path:  "" ,  component:  "front-page"  } , 
    {  path:  "user" ,  component:  "user-list"  } , 
    {  path:  "user/:id" ,  component:  "user-profile"  } , 
] ; 
  
When navigating to /user/123 , the id  property of the view will be provided the paramter from the URL, in this case 123 .

mg.title: Recipes: Dynamic routes
mg.headline: Recipes: Dynamic routes
mg.body:
When creating frontend routing, often you might want to map a route by a given pattern. To achieve this,
dynamic routing is needed. 
Example of a case where dynamic routing could be used is when creating a user view with a dynamic ID to differentiate between multiple users. 
const  routes =  [ 
    {  path:  "" ,  component:  "front-page"  } , 
    {  path:  "user" ,  component:  "user-list"  } , 
    {  path:  "user/:id" ,  component:  "user-profile"  } , 
] ; 
  
When navigating to /user/123 , the id  property of the view will be provided the paramter from the URL, in this case 123 .

n8.title: Getting started: Using a starter
n8.headline: Initial setup
n8.body:
Start by initializing your project with the Open-WC starter 
npm  init @open-wc
  
This will prompt you to generate a starter application for your web component project. You should choose to create
an application, and add whatever optional tooling you need. 
The setup we're using in this tutorial is as follows: 
✔ What would you like to do today? › Scaffold a new project
✔ What would you like to scaffold? › Application
✔ What would you like to add? ›
✔ Would you like to use typescript? › No
✔ What is the tag name of your application/web component? … simplr-router-demo

n9.title: Getting started: Using a starter
n9.headline: Installing the router
n9.body:
npm  install  @simplr-wc/router
  
This command will install the Simplr Router to your project and will be ready to use as soon as it's finished installing.

ro.title: Getting started: Using a starter
ro.headline: Initial setup
ro.body:
Start by initializing your project with the Open-WC starter 
npm  init @open-wc
  
This will prompt you to generate a starter application for your web component project. You should choose to create
an application, and add whatever optional tooling you need. 
The setup we're using in this tutorial is as follows: 
✔ What would you like to do today? › Scaffold a new project
✔ What would you like to scaffold? › Application
✔ What would you like to add? ›
✔ Would you like to use typescript? › No
✔ What is the tag name of your application/web component? … simplr-router-demo

rp.title: Getting started: Using a starter
rp.headline: Installing the router
rp.body:
npm  install  @simplr-wc/router
  
This command will install the Simplr Router to your project and will be ready to use as soon as it's finished installing.

s0.title: Recipes: Dynamic routes
s0.headline: Recipes: Dynamic routes
s0.body:
When creating frontend routing, often you might want to map a route by a given pattern. To achieve this,
dynamic routing is needed. 
Example of a case where dynamic routing could be used is when creating a user view with a dynamic ID to differentiate between multiple users. 
const  routes =  [ 
    {  path:  "" ,  component:  "front-page"  } , 
    {  path:  "user" ,  component:  "user-list"  } , 
    {  path:  "user/:id" ,  component:  "user-profile"  } , 
] ; 
  
When navigating to /user/123 , the id  property of the view will be provided the paramter from the URL, in this case 123 .

wj.title: Recipes: Dynamic routes
wj.headline: Recipes: Dynamic routes
wj.body:
When creating frontend routing, often you might want to map a route by a given pattern. To achieve this,
dynamic routing is needed. 
Example of a case where dynamic routing could be used is when creating a user view with a dynamic ID to differentiate between multiple users. 
const  routes =  [ 
    {  path:  "" ,  component:  "front-page"  } , 
    {  path:  "user" ,  component:  "user-list"  } , 
    {  path:  "user/:id" ,  component:  "user-profile"  } , 
] ; 
  
When navigating to /user/123 , the id  property of the view will be provided the paramter from the URL, in this case 123 .
